Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Deciphering the Neural Code From Perception To Cognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human beings can recognize objects in a highly selective, robust and fast manner. One of the remarkable properties of our recognition machinery is the possibility to selectively recognize objects even after transformations such as rotation, translation, scaling, occlusion and clutter. How the human brain accomplishes recognition is not well understood. More is known about processing of sensory information from receptors to the initial stages in cortex than about the subsequent transformation of perceptual data into cognition. In parallel, over the last decades, major progress has been made in building ever more accurate and sophisticated computers and devices to capture sensory information but progress has been slower in terms of developing algorithms and hardware to automatically interpret the sensory data. With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Gabriel Krieman is undertaking research whose aim is to elucidate the computational steps and algorithms implemented by the cerebral cortex to transform incoming inputs into cognitive functions and behavior. The research focuses on one particular aspect of cognitive experience, the neuronal mechanisms and circuits that underlie visual processing. While vision is only one of many aspects of cognition, lessons learnt from studying visual cortex can also eventually help describe other aspects of cortical function and can pave the way for research on other challenging aspects of cognition. To investigate visual cognition, Dr. Kreiman takes advantage of a rare opportunity to both stimulate and record electrical activity at high spatial and temporal resolution directly from the human brain in epilepsy patients. The study investigates tasks where visual cognition is dissociated from the incoming sensory processing in order to isolate the cognitive operations involved in recognition. The discoveries about the function of biological neural circuits will be applied to develop biophysically-inspired robust machine vision algorithms.

Visual recognition is essential for most everyday tasks including navigating, reading, and identifying objects, faces and emotions. By furthering our understanding of the transformation of perceptual information into cognition, the study is contributing to two broad goals: (1) Helping to alleviate the challenging conditions that involve cognitive disorders through the development of brain-machine interfaces; and (2) Applying knowledge about neuronal circuits to develop computational algorithms to extract cognitive information from sensory data. Building a fast, robust and reliable artificial vision system would have profound repercussions in many areas of science and engineering including pattern recognition, surveillance and security, automatic navigation, clinical image analysis and others. These scientific and engineering advances could in turn translate into important real-world applications of interest for industrial partnerships. Dr. Kreiman pursues these goals by studying the best possible system that can solve visual recognition challenges, the human brain. Understanding the visual system relies on many skills ranging from computer science to engineering to physics to neuroscience to psychology. The project serves well to train a generation of multidisciplinary students who can build on the fundamental science knowledge and apply this knowledge to challenging biological problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: Deciphering the Neural Code From Perception To Cognition

Gabriel Kreiman

 

One of the hallmarks of cognition involves our remarkable ability to rapidly interpret sensory information and make decisions to efficiently act according to those inputs. Even the most advanced computational algorithms currently lack the intelligence to emulate human cognition. We focus on the problem of visual recognition as a paradigmatic example of these high-level cognitive phenomena. We have combined behavioral experiments, invasive neurophysiological recordings and computational models to shed light on how neurons transform sensory percepts into high-level cognition.

 

 We have shown that we can read out visual information from the human brain to decode what subjects are looking at, with only about 150 ms of sensory inputs. These signals are invariant to image transformations including depth rotation, scaling and clutter. Importantly, we have also provided a biologically plausible computational mechanism describing how we can recognize objects from partial information which is consistent with behavioral performance and neural recordings. The ability to perform pattern completion and make inferences from partial cues is fundamental not only to vision but also to other sensory modalities and to other aspects of cognition including decision-making and social interactions. These ideas also led us to investigate the nature of volitional decision-making and the interactions between bottom-up sensory signals and top-down stored information.

 

The work from this award has led to multiple lectures and a new class at Harvard, to multiple peer-reviewed publications in top journals in the field, to the publication of two books by MIT Press and to the dissemination of findings through other means including the organization of conferences, a summer school and workshops at various conferences. This work has also led to training a cadre of interdisciplinary students at multiple levels including high school, undergraduate, graduate and postdocs. These students include both American and international ones, under-represented minorities, students from Harvard as well as several other colleges in the Boston area. Some of these young investigators went on to graduate school or medical school, some of these researchers are now establishing their own independent laboratories, some of them have gone on to establish new start-ups based on the work and experience in the lab. Leveraging on the fundamental support from this project at an early stage of the PI’s career has also played a fundamental role and has led to new awards and obtaining other sources of funding from spin-off projects. Understanding how neurons orchestrate the magic of cognition will have a profound impact in multiple domains including clinical applications (e.g. how to build brain-machine interfaces for prosthetic devices), computational/engineering applications (e.g. how to make truly smart machines) and, equally important, to better understand one of the most fundamental questions of all times, who we are and the nature of conscious cognition.
